Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: This morning, as I was about to head out for my shift at the workshop, I ran into Mrs. Kim in the lobby. She’s always been kind, and as her neighbor, I know I’m expected to be friendly, especially now that a noise complaint has been making the rounds on our floor. She smiled, but I could sense the tension—everyone’s on edge, and I felt the pressure to be extra polite, maybe even reassure her that I’m not the source of the problem. But my mind kept drifting to the job site. As a carpenter, I can’t afford to be late or distracted; safety protocols demand that I thoroughly inspect my tools before any structural work. If I rush, I risk missing something critical, but if I linger here to smooth things over with Mrs. Kim, I’ll be behind schedule. My stomach twisted as I tried to balance the urge to be a good neighbor with the responsibility to keep my crew safe. I could feel both roles pulling at me, each demanding more than I could give at that moment.
